results.title: The Great energy waste
results.brief_description: An evil genius had created an unnatural impulse in Canadians to overcome energy. A scientist and his sardonic dog work to foil his plans.

results.title: The Great Egyptians
results.brief_description:
The true life stories of six of the great kings and queens of ancient Egypt- Part One: The Mystery of Tutankhamen; Who was the boy king? In 1923, his tomb was found by Howard Carter intact, but to this day, we are still uncertain of his lineage.
Part Two: The Real Cleopatra; Cleopatra has often been portrayed as cruel and promiscuous. Evidence now indicates she was a monogamous woman, a devoted mother, and a compassionate queen to her people.
Part Three: King of the Pyramids; The Pharoah Sneferu showed the Egyptians how to construct pyramids and with his genius and determination established Egypt as an international power.
Part Four: Ramses the Great; Ramses II built on a scale unequalled by any ruler in history, bragged about his military prowess, and was fond of listing the names of his two hundred children.
Part Five: The Queen Who Would Be King; Hatsheput wanted to be king, not queen; and she succeeded. Pushing aside her nephew and rightful heir to the throne, Tuthmoses III, she ruled as king of upper and lower Egypt for twenty two years.
Part Six: The Rebel Pharoah; At the end of the eighteenth dynasty the pharoah Amenhotep IV changed his name to Akhenaten and declared there is but one god, Aten the solar disk. Presented by Bob Brier.

results.title: The great dinosaur hunt
results.creator_credit: Reel Images, Location Equipment and Brian Beaton
results.brief_description: Western Australia is one of the oldest areas in the world and contains the earliest fossilised evidence of life walking on earth. This video follows Australian palaeontologist, Dr John Long, and the Dinosaur Club of the Museum of Western Australia (which includes hundreds of children) on their hunt for fossils, bones and footprints of the dinosaurs who once lived in that state. Computer and model animation are used to illustrate the dinosaurs whose relics have been unearthed, some of which are unknown in the Northern Hemisphere, which possibly suggests Australia was the last home of the dinosaurs before their extinction.

results.title: The Great cover-up
results.creator_credit: Texture Films, Henriette Montgomery and Sonya Friedman
results.brief_description: Uses live action and animation to present observations about dress, including its significance as a means of self-expression, its role as part of the total design of an age, and the way in which it reflects prevailing political and social issues.

results.title: The Great chess movie
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Helene Verrier, Gilles Carle and Camille Coudari
results.brief_description: In this Gilles Carle feature documentary on the game of chess, the international chess match is cast as a classic Western shoot-out. Three chess greats dominate the film: Russia’s Anatoly Karpov; Victor Korchnoi, a Russian defector; and American Bobby Fischer. Chess aficionados Camille Coudari and Fernando Arrabal analyse the personalities and strategies of the players and comment on the interplay of politics and chess. Voice and narration by Bondfield Marcoux; editing by Yves Leduc; photography by Pierre Letarte, Thomas Vamos. (Awards: Montreal; San Francisco)

results.title: The Great chase [silent]
results.creator_credit: Castle Films and United World Films
results.brief_description: W. C. Fields earns himself a jot at the bank as a security guard after unwittingly foiling the getaway of bank robbers. Unfortunately he is then taken hostage by one of the robbers in another robbery attempt at the bank and forced to drive the getaway cark, with policemen hot on their tail. Possibly from the feature “The Bank dick” (also known as “The Bank detective), 1940.

results.title: The Great Chase
results.brief_description: Here is a cavalcade of the most hair-raising pursuits in film from the silent era: features sequences from “The Great Train Robbery” by pioneer Edwin S Porter; D.W.Griffith’s “Way Down East” with Lillian Gish; “The Mark of Zorro” starring Douglas Fairbanks Snr; Buster Keaton’s “The General” and many others. It is an exciting, funny and classic treat for young and old alike about the silent era. Rated: G

results.title: The Great Caruso
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Joe Pasternak and Richard Thorpe
results.brief_description: Enrico Caruso was considered one of the greatest tenors ever known. Mario Lanza, himself a renown tenor, plays the title role. Studying Caruso’s recordings over some years, Lanza sings twenty-seven songs with such passion and sentiment that the result is an outstanding and worthy tribute to the talents of both tenors. The story traces Caruso’s career as a cafe singer through to his career at the famous Met. It also follows his happy marriage to Dorothy Benjamin played by Ann Blyth and the troubles he experienced with her family. “The Great Caruso” is a musical feast and includes favourite arias from composers such as Verdi and Puccini. Based on Dorothy Caruso’s biography of her husband.

results.title: The Great Canadian train ride
results.brief_description: In 1955 the Canadian Pacific Railway inaugurated the ‘Canadian’, a new train designed to offer the ultimate in rail luxury. It was then and remains today one of the longest train journeys in the world. VIA Rail took on the daunting task of restoring all of the original lounge Park Cars, the observation dome cars and the dining and sleeping cars. The restored cars are now in service on the northern route of the Super Continental. Doug Jones boards the train in Toronto and documents its journey to Vancouver across Canada. A history of the Canadian Pacific Railway is given, as well as a behind the scenes look at the operations of the train. Doug Jones also looks at tourist destinations along the way.

results.title: The Great Canadian shield
results.brief_description: The rock of the great Canadian Shield was formed two billion years ago. Now its many minerals—gold, nickel, copper, mica, feldspar, iron and magnesium—are mined as essential ingredients in Canadian industry.
